description: Typography & Reading Experience - Establish clear visual hierarchy through line spacing, evaluate desktop card width behavior, and audit color accessibility for WCAG AA compliance

userStories.title: Line Spacing - Soft Wraps vs Sentences
userStories.description: As a learner, I want clear visual hierarchy in text spacing so that I can easily distinguish between line wraps within sentences, source-to-translation groupings, and separate sentences/examples.
acceptanceCriteria: Wrapped lines within one sentence have tight line-height (~1.4)
Translations tightly grouped with source text (small gap, ~0.25rem)
Spacing between different sentences/examples clearly larger (~1.2-1.5em)
Visual hierarchy shows which translation belongs to which source
No ambiguity about sentence boundaries
Works on both mobile and desktop viewports
Screenshots show before/after comparison with annotations
Test with various content: short sentences, long wrapped sentences, multiple examples, with/without translations
Typecheck passes: npx tsc --noEmit
Verify in browser using Chrome DevTools MCP

userStories.title: Desktop Card Width Expansion for Long Content
userStories.description: As a user, I want desktop cards to handle long content appropriately so that I can read efficiently without excessive scrolling or readability issues from overly wide lines.
acceptanceCriteria: Evaluate both approaches (fixed width + scrolling vs expansion) with real content using Chrome DevTools MCP
Take screenshots of both behaviors
Consider typography principles (optimal line length: 50-75 chars)
Document decision with reasoning
If implementing change: Update card width classes
If implementing change: Test on various desktop viewport sizes
If implementing change: Verify no horizontal scroll on standard viewports
Document decision in progress notes
Typecheck passes: npx tsc --noEmit

userStories.title: Color Accessibility Improvements
userStories.description: As a user with visual impairments or color-blindness, I want the app to meet WCAG AA accessibility standards so that I can effectively use all features regardless of my vision capabilities.
acceptanceCriteria: All app colors documented with hex values and usage
Contrast ratios calculated for all text/background pairs
Failing combinations identified with specific locations
Alternative colors suggested for non-compliant pairs
Color-blindness simulation performed (protanopia, deuteranopia, tritanopia, achromatopsia)
WCAG AA compliance achieved for all text (4.5:1 normal, 3:1 large)
Updated color tokens implemented in config
Screenshots show before/after comparison
Visual regression testing on key components (cards, navbar, buttons, badges)
Accessibility guidelines documented
Lighthouse accessibility score > 90
Typecheck passes: npx tsc --noEmit
Verify in browser using Chrome DevTools MCP
